ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Adobe Premiere, Photoshop, Procreate, greenscreen, rotoscope, stop-motion, and a bit of audio design
I learned collage, stop-motion animation with photos, greenscreen, rotoscoping, Adobe Premiere, some introductory film language.
Learned a lot of technical animating skills as well as how to begin think about animation as a discipline.
Many different techniques used in digital animation as well as some insights on the creative process

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Yale art students are chronic procrastinators, so I hope in the future more firm deadlines could be set to keep us on track, especially for the rotoscope project. However, I think there was great strength to the course in that Mike showed us a lot of historical animation as well as contemporary animation and provided a lot of guidance in our own projects. We watched and analyzed a lot of animation, not just from large studios but many from smaller creators as well.

The curriculum pacing is just right, so the workload does not feel too overwhelming even though it is a lot. The professor well-understands the labor that animation requires and is understanding of students while spurring them onward. I really like how most classes are demonstrations or critiques. It keeps students motivated to keep working on their projects and get feedback from classmates and the professor. Professor Rader tends to let students talk more during critiques so depending on whether you like to know what the teacher thinks in particular, this may be good. Either way, I recommend approaching him after class to discuss your work more in detail to learn more from his expertise. One thing I wish is that all the in-class demonstrations of how to use software or how we analyzed some examples of animated films were uploaded to Canvas so that I could've reviewed them when working on my projects.
Loved the open-ended projects that allowed us to pursue our own artistic voices!
Class content and workload was perfect

I enjoyed the class time but honestly felt that the class periods were too long. There were times when I felt I could have benefited from spending time working on my projects instead of some of the class activities. the material was interesting, just sometimes a bit too condensed into one period.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but be prepared to work hard. Animation is no joke. However, if you dedicate yourself to this commitment you will be surprised at how much you can accomplish!
Yes! Professor is really nice, this course opens your eyes to the wide range of possibilities of animation from experimental/abstract to film/narrative, but be prepared to work hard.
Yes. It is an amazing class for those who like animation and a great professor
